Dialogue: And my father?

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: Sheriff Buddy was a different story. Long as Roderick throw his weight the right way on election day, make sure all the colored get out to vote- we was called colored back then, if you was polite--maybe throw a barbecue for the right people now and then, things was peaceful. That Sheriff Wade, though, he took an awful big bite.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: People didn't complain?

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: Not if they was colored or Meskin. Not if they wanted to keep breathin'.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Do you remember the last time you saw him?

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: I seen him in our place the last week before he gone missin'.

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: He used to come in whilst we was in full swing, make people nervous. Had him a smile like the Grim Reaper--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Pour it.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Pour it.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I know you?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Name's Otis.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Otis what?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Payne.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: One of Cleroe Payne's boys?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I sent your Daddy to the farm once.

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: I know that.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Why you think that was?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Some crop needed pickin' and the man was shorthanded.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: As I remember it was because he had a sassy mouth on him. Must run in the family--You wouldn't be runnin' numbers out of this club, now, would you, son?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Runnin' numbers illegal.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Runnin' numbers without I know about it is both illegal and unhealthy. You remember that.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Whoah, son. You're not finished. Pour his.

Speaker: young hollis
Dialogue: I prefer it in the bottle--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Shut up, Hollis. Pour.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: How come you don't took familiar?

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: Been away. Up to Houston.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Houston, huh? I hear they let you boys run wild up there.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Aw--look what you done now. Better get something to wipe it up, son.

Speaker: young otis
Dialogue: You spilt it, you wipe it up.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I told you to do something. Are you gonna hop to it, or are we gonna have a problem?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Don't want to turn tail in front of your people. I understand.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Come on, Houston, give it a try! Come to Poppa--

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Don't mind him, Sheriff. Boy's just a bit slow, is all. He don't mean nothin' by it--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: That the problem, son?  You Slow?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Otis, apologize to the Sheriff--

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: You got him too scared to peep, Sheriff. Maybe if you put that gun up--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You telling me what to do, Roderick?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: No, Sheriff, I'm just--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: What's this I see? Is that whiskey in them glasses on the Bar? Roderick, I'm gonna have to cite you for a violation of state law--

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: This is a club, Sheriff--you been in here--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: And people better clear out of here! Now!

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You learn how to act your place, son. This idn't Houston.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I didn't understand the spot I was putting Roderick in.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: And that was the last time you saw him?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Oh--I think he came in one more time with Hollis and--naw, your Daddy wasn't with them. Made their monthly pickup. Roderick wasn't in so I just kept my mouth good and shut and handed over that envelope.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That was the night he disappeared?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Could of been. That was white people's business.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: And when my father was Sheriff?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What was your deal with him?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Buddy was more a part of the big picture--county political machine, chamber of commerce, zoning board if I kept those people happy, he was pretty much on my side.  Whenever somebody thought--they start up another bar for the black  folks, they'd be--how should I put this? They'd be officially discouraged.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He ever accept cash for a favor?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I don't recall a prisoner ever died in your father's custody. I don't recall a man in this town--Black, White, Mexican--who'd hesitate a minute before they'd call on Buddy Deeds to solve a problem. More than that I wouldn't like to say.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: If you had your way I wouldn't have any friends.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Oh, come on, Amado--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: Just 'cause I'm not like Little Miss Honor Roll here--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Leave your sister out of it.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: You and all of the teachers in this dump--your story's over, so you don't want anybody else to have fun.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: You jerk--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: I'm not talking to you. You don't have any friends.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: Who'd want to be friends with that bunch of pachuco wannabes?

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: I don't pretend I came over on the Mayflower--

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: And those stupid girls who hang out with them--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: Just shut up.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: Not if you have half a brain in your head.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Of course you can.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: It doesn't have anything to do with being smart.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: What I'm saying is, I don't see the point. You had your chance when the dedication committee was meeting--

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: I've got new information--

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: 1963, they dam up the north branch to make Lake Pescadero. A whole little town disappears--

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: People had been living in Perdido for over a hundred years. Mexicans and Chicanos are deported, evicted, moved forcibly out of their houses by our local hero, Buddy Deeds, and his department--

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: There was a bill from the state legislature--

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Families were split apart, a whole community was destroyed--

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: --and who ends up with lakefront property bought for a fraction of the market price? Buddy Deeds, Sheriff of Rio County, and his Chief Deputy, Hollis Pogue.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You finished?

Speaker: danny
Dialogue: Look, I'm not after you, Sam.  I just think people in town ought to know the full story on Buddy Deeds.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That makes two of us.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Otis Payne was never embarrassed about a thing in his life.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Dad--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: He didn't leave, he moved three houses down with one of my mother's best friends.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Dad--?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: "Hey, Delmore, where's your Daddy?"

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Big O was always there with a  smile or a loan or a free drink.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Dad, can I talk to you about track?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Not that much.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Dad, I talked to the track coach--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: I thought we already had this out? Next year, if your grades are high enough--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: I have a B average.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: How many B-average students do you think they take at West Point?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: No, we don't.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Sabado por la noche--Is, es el  mas seguero--a cruzar por la  manana y pues tendremos que esperar--[Friday night--Yes, that's the safest--I'll cross in the morning and then we'll have to wait--]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Off the phone, by we've got people waiting. Andale!

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Donde estan sus guantes? Tonta! Quiere matar a mis clientes? [Where are your gloves? Stupid! You want to kill my customers?]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: These ones coming up are getting stupider every year.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Maybe you're just getting less patient.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: If they're going to survive here, they have to know how to work, Elalco! Adelante! Los clientes esperan!

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Well, you hire illegals--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Nobody is illegal in my cafe! They've got green cards, they've got relatives who were born here--if they only had a little common sense I'd be very happy.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: If you spent a little more time training them--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Did you come here to tell me how to run my business?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: No. I was wondering if you'd like to take a trip down south with us. Maybe see where you grew up--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Why would I want to go there?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Oh, come on--you must be curious how it's changed. Amado is into this big Tejano roots thing and I've never been further than Ciudad Leon--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: You want to see Mexicans, open your eyes and look around you. We're up to our ears in them.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Mami, how old were you when my father--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: He was killed.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Right. When he was killed.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: A little older than Paloma is now.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: How come you never got married again?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: There must have been somebody.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I was too busy.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Nobody's too busy.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Maybe now. It was different back then. I had this place, I was doing all the shopping, all the cooking. What do I need some chulo with grease under his nails to drink up the profit?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I don't mean Fernando.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Mami, the first time I brought him home, those were your exact words-- "some chulo with grease under his nails."

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I never said that.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: You made it pretty damn clear you thought he was nobody.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I felt that you could do better for yourself--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: What? Become a nun? You didn't want me going out with Anglos--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I never said that. It was just that boy--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: "That boy"--Mami, say his name for chrissakes!

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: You people are stealing my money-- Entiende? Robandome?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Su madre? [Your mother?]

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Si.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Lo siento [My condolences.]

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Now I'm just as liberal as the next guy--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: If the next guy's a redneck.

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: --but I gotta say I think there's something to this cold climate business. I mean, you go to the beach- what do you do? Drink a few beers, wait for a fish to flop up on the sand. Can't build no civilization that way. You got a hard winter coming, though, you got to plan ahead, and that gives your cerebral cortex a workout.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Good deal you were born down here, then.

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: You joke about it, Sam, but we are in a state of crisis. The lines of demarcation has gotten fuzzy--to run a sucessfull civilization you got to have lines of demarcation between right and wrong, between this one and that one--your Daddy understood that. He was like the whatchacallit-- the referee for this damn menudo we got down here. He understood how most people don't want their sugar and salt in the same jar.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You mixed drinks bad as you mix metaphors, you be out of a job.

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Take that pair over in the corner--

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Place like this, twenty years ago, Buddy woulda been, on them two--

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: --but just as a kind of safety tip.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah. I bet he would.

Speaker: cody
Dialogue: Old Sam stood for somethin', you know? The day that man died they broke the goddamn mold.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: So where does that put us?

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Well--I don't see what's changed. No - PDA's, no necking on the obstacle course.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: Seriously.

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Seriously, I think we should get married.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: We been through this before--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: We should just do it.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: And if I get a shot at a promotion somewhere--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: You could take it--

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: It's up or out these days, Cliff. Say I get transferred to a different post--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: I'd quit the Army for you, if it came to that.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: Man's gonna retire in two years and he offer to quit. Big goddamn deal.

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Sheriff--hi--this is Sergeant--this is Priscilla Worth.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Pleased to meet you.

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Sheriff Deeds was in on our archeological find yesterday.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: It true they gonna build a shopping mall out there?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: If certain people have their way, it's going to be a new jail.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: Damn. Maybe we got in the wrong business. They closin' down military bases left and right, puttin' up jails like 7-11 stores.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Do either of you have any idea when they stopped using that site as a rifle range?

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: They stopped training infantry there in the late '50s. It was just a playground for the jackrabbits till they gave it to the county last year.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: You know who it was they dug up?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Not for sure yet. But I kind of wish they hadn't.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Es muy lindo, su coche--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: En ingles Enrique. This is the United States. We speak English.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Is very beautiful, your car.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Good night, Enrique. She slides into the car--

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Buenas noches, Senora Cruz. Enrique walks in the opposite direction--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Carolyn--knock that off for a minute.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Black Seminoles?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Hobby of mine. Got some artifacts, couple pieces one of your men out at the base made. Free admission.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: That where he was shot?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: That's where he fell.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: You get much of that in here?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: It's a bar. People come together, drink, fall in love, fall out of love, air their grudges out--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Deal drugs in the bathroom--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: If I thought it would help I'd put up a sign telling them not to. Right under the one about the employees washing their hands.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: This here's Carolyn. Honey, this is my son, Delmore.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Nice to meet you, Ma'am.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: I'll be in back waiting for that delivery.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: So.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: So tell me why I shouldn't make this place off-limits.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: This is an official visit, then--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: I assume a lot of your business is from our people.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Your boys out there cooped up together, need somewhere they can let the steam out. If they're Black, there's not but one place in this town they feel welcome. Been that way since before you were born.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: We have an enlisted man's club at the post.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Well, you're the Man out there now, aren't you? It's your call.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I been hearing rumors about this new commander coming for a couple weeks now. Boys say they heard he's a real hard case. Spit-and-polish man. Full- bird colonel name of Payne, they say-- Bet you never figured you end up back here.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: The Army hands you a command, you go wherever it is.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: I hear things, too.  People call you the Mayor of Darktown.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Over the years, this is the one place that's always been there. I loan a little money out, settle some arguments. Got a cot in the back- people get afraid to go home they can spend the night. There's not enough of us to run anything in this town- the white people are mostly out on the lake now and the Mexicans hire each other. There's the Holiness Church and there's Big O's place.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: And people make their choice--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: A lot of 'em choose both. There's not like a borderline between the good people and the bad people--you're not either on one side or the other--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I gonna meet that family of yours?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Why would you want to do that?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Because I'm your father.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: You'll get official notification when I make my decision. He is out the door--Otis pulls himself a beer as Carolyn steps back out--

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: So that's him--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Yeah--that's him. Got two, three thousand people under him out there, you count the civilians.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: That must be a laugh a minute.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Seems like we have another one every week.

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: We're building up tourism, Sam--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: People come here to catch bass and to get laid at the Boy's Town in Cuidad Leon--

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: Sam--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You ought to put up a banner-- "Frontera, Texas: Gateway to Cut- Rate Pussy"--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Rather have that than the ten-foot- high catfish statue--

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: I got Eddie Richter at the Sentinel to kill that story.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: The Perdido thing?

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: He agreed it wasn't exactly news--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Danny's gonna be out for blood the next time.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We don't need a new jail.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We're already renting cells to the Feds for their overflow--

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: There was a mandate in the last election--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It wouldn't happen to be your construction company gonna get the bid on building this thing, would it, H.L. And Jorge, you wouldn't be thinking about a couple dozen new jobs to dangle in front of the voters--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: We need a drug rehab program, we need a new elementary school--

Speaker: jorge
Dialogue: There isn't money allocated for that. But a jail--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Look, I'm not gonna campaign against your deal here, but if anybody asks me, I got to tell them the truth. We-- don't--need--a new jail.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: When you backed me you needed somebody named Deeds to bump the other fella out of office.  Hey, folks--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Let's get this thing over with.

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: Never thought I'd see the day a buddy of mine was dating a woman with three up and three down on her shoulder.

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: I think it's beyond what you'd call dating.

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: You going to get married?

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: You met her family? They gonna be cool about you being a white guy?

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Priscilla says they think any woman over 30 who isn't married must be a lesbian. She figures they'll be so relieved I'm a man--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: Always heartwarming to see a prejudice defeated by a deeper prejudice.  But marriage, man--I did two tours in Southeast Asia and I was married for five years--I couldn't tell you which experience was worse.

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Hey, Mikey--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: I knew she was Japanese going into it, but she didn't tell me the ninja assassin part--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Mikey--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: Her parents acted like I was gonna blow my nose on their curtains--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Mikey--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: If I stayed out past ten with the guys she'd go into her Madame Butterfly routine--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: Mikey look at this--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: What--it's a bullet. I'm lousy with bullets here.

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: This is the stuff we picked up the other day, right? The rest of this is all .30 caliber--

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: They were using M-1's, yeah--

Speaker: cliff
Dialogue: What's it doing on a rifle range?

Speaker: mikey
Dialogue: We better call that Sheriff.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Sometime in the early '70s a reporter from a national magazine was talking to the governor of our Lone Star state, and he asked him, "Governor, what's your ideal of what a real Texan ought to be?" Governor said, "That's easy, son- you just go down to Rio County and get a look at Sheriff Buddy Deeds."

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: --and he's somebody who probably knew Buddy better than any of us, Sam--would you say a few words?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You folks who remember my father knew him as Sheriff. But at home he was also judge, jury

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: --and executioner.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: This is a real honor you're doing him today, and if Buddy was around I'm sure his hat size would be gettin' bigger every minute.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'll have to find someplace new to duck out.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I do appreciate it, and wherever he is, Buddy's puttin' the beer on ice for the bunch of you. Thank you.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: And now my fellow Council member and one of Frontera's most respected businesswomen, Mrs. Mercedes Cruz, will do the honors for us.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Nice to see you, Mrs. Cruz.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Field trip?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Lunch hour. My next class isn't till nine-thirty.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Want to take a walk?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Your mother still doesn't like me.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I can't name anybody she does like these days.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I see she built a place up here by the river.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: A real palace. She rattles around alone in that thing--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: She's done well for herself--on her own and all--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: So she tells me three times a week.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I thought you got through that pretty well.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: They cooked the whole thing up without asking me.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: People liked him.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Most people did, yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I remember him watching me once. When I was little--before you and I--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I was on the playground with all the other kids, but I thought he was only looking at me. I was afraid he was going to arrest me--he had those eyes, you know--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Weird what you remember.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Your boy, there--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Amado.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Nice-looking kid.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: He hates me.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: With Paloma, it's more like she pities and tolerates me- totally age- appropriate. But Amado--he's--he's never been book-smart. Had a hard time learning to read. Me being a teacher and caring about those things is like an embarrassment--like a betrayal.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Fernando did okay, and he dropped out--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Fernando wasn't pissed off at everybody. He just wanted to fix their cars.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It might just be the age. I spent my first fifteen years trying to be just like Buddy and the next fifteen trying to give him a heart attack.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: So why did you come back here, Sam?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Got divorced, I wasn't gonna work for my father-in-law anymore. The fellas down here said they'd back me--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: You don't want to be Sheriff.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I got to admit it's not what I thought it'd be. Back When Buddy had it-- hell, I'm just a jailer. Run a 60- room hotel with bars on the windows.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: It can happen so sudden, can't it? Being left out on your own.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You've got your mother, your kids--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: They've got me. Different thing.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Remember this?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I should get back.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Pilar--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Looks real bad if the teacher's late for class. It's really nice to talk with you, Sam.

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: You going to tell her?

Speaker: young pilar
Dialogue: You going to tell him?

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: He doesn't need to know all my business.

Speaker: young pilar
Dialogue: He's gonna find out.

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: So? What's he gonna do, arrest us?

Speaker: young pilar
Dialogue: It's supposed to be some big sin, even if you love each other.

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: You believe that?

Speaker: young pilar
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Me neither.

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: Private Johnson!

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Sergeant?

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: Report to Dr. Innis at the clinic.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I'm feeling okay--

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: I'm very happy to hear that, Private. Now you go put some pee-pee in a cup for Dr. Innis and I'll be feeling okay, too.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: You're testing me?

Speaker: priscilla
Dialogue: You and one hundred nineteen other fortunate individuals. Put it in gear.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Yes, Sergeant.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Excellent performance, my friend. The judge was very impressed.

Speaker: shadow
Dialogue: You don't need to cuff me.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You been talking so much trash today, you made us think you're a dangerous criminal. Be a good boy, now--

Speaker: shadow
Dialogue: You're the one who's a good boy. Man say "fetch" and you fetch--

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Just doing my job.

Speaker: shadow
Dialogue: White man just using you to keep the Black man down.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: This isn't Houston, my friend. We pretty much running things now. Our good day has come.

Speaker: shadow
Dialogue: You suckers haven't had a good day since the Alamo.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Andale, amigo,

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Lupe? Get me the rangers up in Austin--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Otra vez los mojados--[Wetbacks again--]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Hello? Border Patrol?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Who is that? Come out here where I can see you!

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You sonofabitch--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Zack?

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: Hey Sam. Sorry 'bout that.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: We had about a dozen wets come over just upriver. They ran into one of our posts--it was like a breakshot on a pool table, illegals runnin' every which way.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I haven't seen anybody come by.

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: We'll get 'em--  So you livin' out here now?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah. It's quiet--

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: I heard about that deal for your father--You must be real proud.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: The stories people tell, he was a real colorful fella--

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: Well--back on the clock. You see any of our neighbors from the south, let 'em know I'm lookin' for 'em.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: 'Night--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: For a while.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: First bullet entered beneath the left eye, severing the optical nerve and exiting from top rear of skull causing tissue damage

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Morning, Sheriff.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hey, Pete. How's it going?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Time marches on.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: How much you got left?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Three months.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You stop growing that loco weed at your place, you'd see a lot more daylight.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: It was for personal consumption.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You're going to smoke an acre and a half of marijuana?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: I got a bad stomach. It helps me digest.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Your father never bothered me about it. Leastways not till the drug people got on his back in the late '60s.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I thought he busted you a couple times.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Different charge. I had a still. Made my own mescal.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: That's how I ruined my stomach.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm surprised he bothered with it.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He was afraid I was going to poison somebody. Your father tried to do good for people--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: So I've heard--

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: And your mother was a saint. That summer I built the patio at your house? She made me lunch every day.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Well, you were working there--

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: It could have just been a box lunch from the jail.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You built our patio while you  were on the county?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Out in the fresh air, nice gringo lady making you pies--who's gonna sit back in a little jail cell all day? Sheriff Buddy, man. Como el no hay dos. And after that cabron Charley Wade--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I've heard Wade was a bit tough on the Mexicans--

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: He murdered Eladio Cruz. That tough enough for you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Murdered him?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Chucho Montoya saw it with his own eyes. Shot him in cold blood.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: You're out early.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Haven't seen much of you at the jail lately.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I been working on a few things.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Uh-huh.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I'm going over to the other side.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: The Republicans?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No--to Mexico. I've got to talk to somebody.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: They got telephones.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Gotta be in person.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Sam? I--the Committee--you know Jorge and H.L. and all--they asked me--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: They want you to stand for Sheriff next election.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You'd do a good job.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: How 'bout you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't know if I'll still want it.

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: I didn't want to be going around your back.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I appreciate you telling me.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You think we need a new jail?

Speaker: ray
Dialogue: Well, it's a complicated issue--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah, Ray, you'd be a hell of a Sheriff.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I'm only going to have you for two more years. If you decide not to go on to college--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: I can't take any more school.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: --you're going to be on your own.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: So I'm worried about you. I don't want you to end up in jail like your friends.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: They're not going to jail.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Don't try to con me, Amado. You knew how they got all those things.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: Just some rich Anglo out on the lake. Don't even live here all year.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: That makes it okay?

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: They stole our land--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Save your breath. That line doesn't cut it with me.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: How do you think you're going to make a living?

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: I can fix cars.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: You can fix old cars. Mr. Washburn told me that the cars they're making now are all computerized--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: You think I can't learn that?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I think you can learn whatever you want to. I just don't see you doing it. If you want to settle for--

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: I'm not settling for anything. I like cars, it's just not a move up the ladder to you, so you think it's a waste.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: That isn't true.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: Oh, come on--you and Grandma think anybody who works with their hands is a peasant. When Dad--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: If you grew up to he anywhere near as good a man as your father was, I would be happy! I would be thrilled.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: It's my life. If I want to fuck it up, that's my business.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I said pretty much the same thing to my mother when I was your age.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: And what did she do?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Two years at hard labor, Our Lady of Perpetual Help.

Speaker: amado
Dialogue: Catholic school, nasty.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Honey, I think you're smart and you're good and I love you. So don't act like an idiot, all right?

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: Recycling, right? We invented that. The government doesn't have to tell people to do it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You own this place?

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: This place, the one across the street, four other ones around Ciudad Leon-- soy el Rey de las Llantas. King of the Tires. Lots of your people rollin' back over that bridge on my rubber.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You lived in the States for a while?

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: Fifteen years in El Paso.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Made some money, came back here--

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: Something like that.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You ever know a fella named Eladio Cruz?

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: You the sheriff of Rio County, right? Un jefe muy respetado. Step over this line.

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: Ay, que milagro! You're not the Sheriff of nothing anymore- just some tejano with a lot of questions I don't have to answer.

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: Bird flying south-you think he sees that line? Rattlesnake, javelina-- whatever you got--halfway across that line they don't start thinking different. So why should a man?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Your government always been pretty happy to have that line. The question's just been where to draw it

Speaker: chucho
Dialogue: My government can go fuck itself, and so can yours. I'm talking about people here--men. Mi amigo Eladio Cruz is giving some friends of his a lift in his camion one day--

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Donde vas, Chucho, Tienes que quedar escondido! [Shit, CHUCHO you got to stay hidden!]

Speaker: young chucho
Dialogue: Voy a romper las rinones si no hago pipi--[I'm gonna bust my kidneys if I don't pee--]

Speaker: young chucho
Dialogue: Los demas son tan espantados que prefieran mojar sus pantalones. [The other guys are so scared they'd rather wet their pants.]

Speaker: young chucho
Dialogue: Mira, Eladio [Look!]

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Muchachos! Escondases! [Boys! Hide yourselves!]

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Hola, amgio. Problemas de llanta? [Hey, friend. Tire problems?]

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: No hay de que. Tengo otra. [No problem, I've got another.]

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: What's in the back?

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Not much, jefe. Some watermelons.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: I heard somebody been haulin' wets on this road.

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: I haven't seen anybody doing that.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: This same person been bragging all over the county how he don't have to cut that big gringo Sheriff in on it-- he can run his own operation 'thout any help. Como se llama, amigo?

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Eladio Cruz.

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You know this road got a bad reputation, Eladio--

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Reputation?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Bandidos, Injuns--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: There's many an unfortunate soul been ambushed out on this stretch. Hope you're carrying some protection.

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Protection?

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: You carryin' a firearm, son?  Don't lie to me now.

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Si--tengo escopeto--just a shotgun--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Just a shotgun, huh? Better let me take a look at that.

Speaker: young hollis
Dialogue: Oh no--oh Jesus--oh my Lord--

Speaker: wade
Dialogue: Little greaser sonofabitch been running a goddarn bus service. Think he can make a fool out of Charley Wade! Get them wets outta the back, Hollis, see what we've got--

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: It happens again, we build a fence around it.

Speaker: zack
Dialogue: Podemos ganar muchas batallas pero la guerra ya es perdido--[We can win a lot of battles but the war's already been lost--]

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: You wan' something to drink?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: --but longhorns are hard to come by these days.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You sell much out here?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: How am I gonna sell things if nobody comes by? This stretch of road runs between Nowheres and Nothin' Much.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hell of a spot to put a business.

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: But you don't see much competition, do you?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: These things used to sell like hotcakes. Now, if it can't play those discs, they won't look at it.

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: I like it here. Once I tried going onto that reservation to live. Couldn't take the politics. Damn Indian'll drive you crazy with that, Now your father--this wasn't what he had in mind at all. He come out of Korea, he had this Chevy with too much engine in it. He'd come roarin' up and down this road all hours of the day and night,looking for somebody to race.

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: Buffalo chips. Fella in Santa Fe told me he sells these as fast as the buffalo can squeeze 'em out.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: So when did Buddy leave?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: For Frontera? Hell, I can't remember dates no more. I do recall it was after an affair of the heart had gone sour on him. He almost took some poor fella's head off at the Legion in Arroyo Grande, and figured it was time to move on.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You think he killed anybody in Korea?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: They don't hand those medals out for hidin'in your foxhole. Would you buy this?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No--

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: Me neither.

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: If he hadn't found that Deputy job, I believe Buddy might've gone down the other path, got into some serious trouble. Settled him right down. That and your mother. 'Course he had that other one later.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Another woman?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: Your mother wasn't one to get chased off her patch. Half the damn county knew and nobody thought the worse of her for seein' it through.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You know who it was?

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: The other one? Hell, at my age, every time you learn a new name you got to forget an old one. Your head's all crowded up--here it is--

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: This big fella was sleepin' in a crate at Cisco's junkyard right when I looked to see what was in it. Jumped up at my face--scared me so bad I killed him without thinkin'.

Speaker: wesley
Dialogue: Gotta be careful where you're pokin'-- who knows what you'll find.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I don't think you can take it personally--

Speaker: molly
Dialogue: I'd like to see them spend a day pulling 14-year-olds off of each other--I should get combat pay--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I have new respect for some of my kids, meeting the parents they've been dealt--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: See you, Molly.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: Steve called for you.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Steve?

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: Steve. Board of Education Steve who likes you? He goes for us hot-blooded Mexican girls, I can tell.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Spanish, please. My mother would have a heart attack.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: Your mother's family is Spanish?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Sure, they go back to Cortez. When he rode by, they were squatting in a hut cooking hamsters for dinner.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: You got to be interested in somebody. All you do is work.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: All my mother does is work. That's how you get to be Spanish.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: How 'bout the Sheriff?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: The Sheriff.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: The old-high-school-heartthrob Sheriff. I thought you were crazy about each other. He's available, you're available--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I'm unmarried. I'm not available.

Speaker: marisol
Dialogue: You told me one time it was true love.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Nobody stays in love for twenty-three years.

Speaker: buddy
Dialogue: Goddammit!

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: What the hell are you doing? You fucking asshole!

Speaker: buddy
Dialogue: How old is that girl? Goddammit, where's your goddam sense?

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: You got no fuckin' right! You stay out of my fuckin' life!

Speaker: buddy
Dialogue: Gimme the keys--gimme the goddamn car keys, son--

Speaker: buddy
Dialogue: You drive her home and tell her mother where we found her--

Speaker: young sam
Dialogue: You leave her the fuck alone!

Speaker: buddy
Dialogue: You just shut that filthy mouth, son. I'll deal with you when we get home--

Speaker: young pilar
Dialogue: Please, don't tell my mother! She's gonna kill me!

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Follow me.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: We thought we were something, didn't we?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I look at my kids in school--tenth, eleventh graders. That's who we were. Children.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I mean what did we know about anything?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: When Nando died--it was so sudden--I was kind of in shock for awhile. Then I woke up and there was the whole rest of my life and I didn't have any idea what to do with it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You know the other day, you asked why I came back?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I came back 'cause you were here.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: My mother hasn't changed the songs

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: How come it feels the same?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I don't know. It just feels good. Always did.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: So what are we gonna do about this?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: More, I hope.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: How long have you lived here?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Two years.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: There's nothing on the walls. No pictures--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't have kids. Other pictures--I don't know--it's nothing I want to look back on.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Like your story is over.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I've felt that way, yeah.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: It isn't. Not by a long shot. He holds her and they lie silently for a moment--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Pilar--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What was your father's name?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Eladio. Eladio. Cruz.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: She finally got in--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: It's Saturday.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: You got in late last night.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Yeah. I had uhm--school business.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: Can I get this?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Nobody really wears that stuff, Paloma.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: I could name five girls at school who have one just like it--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Enough with the clothes--

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: Just 'cause you went to Catholic school and wore a uniform.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I only went for my last two years.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: How come?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Oh, my mother wanted to keep me away from away from boys.

Speaker: paloma
Dialogue: Did it work?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Morning, Hollis.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Sam! Quite a do the other day. It meant a lot to folks that you said something.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You thought any more about our murder?

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: We have a murder?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Charley Wade.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: I wish I could tell you I remembered something new, but I can't.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I got an idea what happened.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I think somewhere between Roderick Bledsoe's club and his house, Wade ran into Buddy Deeds. I think Buddy put a bullet in him, waited for him to die, threw him in the trunk of the Sheriff's car and drove him out by the Army post, I think he buried him under four feet of sand and never looked back.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: You lived in the man's house what-- seventeen, eighteen years? And you didn't get to know him any better than that?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I got to go see somebody in San Antonio today. Your memory gets any better, I'll be back tonight.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Spanish in Florida called him Juan Caballo. John Horse.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: He a Black man or an Indian?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Both.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: He was part of the Seminole Nation, got pushed down into the Everglades in pioneer days. African people who run off from the slaveholders hooked up with them, married up, had children. When the Spanish give up Florida, the U.S.Army come down to move all them Indian peoples off to Oklahoma--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: The Trail of Tears.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: They teaching that now?  Good. Only a couple of 'em held out--this man, John Horse, and his friend Wild Cat, and a fella name of Osceola. Army put all of them in prison and Osceola died, but them other two escaped and put together a fighting band and held out another ten, fifteen years. Beat Zach Taylor and a thousand troops at Lake Okeechobee.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: So they stayed in Florida?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: They got tired of fighting, went to the Indian Territories for a while. But the slave-raiders were on 'em even there, and one night they packed up and nearly the whole band rode down to Mexico. Crossed at Eagle Pass.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Men worked for Santa Anna down there, waited out the Civil War. The land wasn't much to feed people on, so in 1870 they come north and put up at Fort Duncan and the men joined up what was called the Seminole Negro Indian Scouts. Best trackers either side of the border. Bandits, rustlers, Texas rednecks, Kiowa, Comanche--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: They fought against the Indians?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Same as they done in Mexico.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: But they were Indians themselves.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: They were in the Army. Like your father.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: You know who I am?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I got a pretty good guess.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: That guy who got shot--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: You didn't go telling your father you were here?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Are you kidding? And face a court- martial?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: He's a pretty tough old man, huh?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: No sports if I don't keep a B average, no TV on school nights, no PDA's--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: PDA?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Public Display of Affection. Every time he moves up a rank, it's like he's got to tighten the screws a little more--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Well--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: I mean, just 'cause he didn't--you know--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Didn't have a father?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: He's still pissed off about it.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: When you're his age you'll still be pissed off about him.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: So how come you got into all this?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: These are our people. There were Paynes in Florida, Oklahoma, Piedras Negras--couple of 'em won the whatsit-- Congressional Medal Of Honor--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: So I'm part-Indian?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: By blood you are. But blood only means what you let it.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: My father says the day you're  born you start from scratch, no breaks and no excuses, and you got to pull yourself up on your own.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Well, he's living proof of that, son. Living proof.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Private Johnson, are you unhappy in the Army?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: No, sir--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Then how would you explain the fact that out of one hundred twenty people we tested, you're the only one who came up positive for drugs?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: When you were given the opportunity to enlist, a kind of contract was agreed upon. I think the Army has honored its part of that agreement.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Yes, sir--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Do you believe in what we're doing here, Private Johnson?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I-I can do the job, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: You don't sound too enthusiastic.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I am, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: What exactly do you think your job is, Private?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Follow orders. Do whatever they say.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Who's "they"?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: The--the officers.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: And that's the job? Nothing about serving your country?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: These aren't trick questions, Private. You'll be given an Article 15 and be going into the ADCAP Program one way or the other. What happens after that is up to you. I'm just trying to understand how somebody like you thinks.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: You really want to know, sir?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: It's their country. This is one of the best deals they offer.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: How do you think I got to be a colonel?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Work hard, be good at your job. Sir. Do whatever they tell you.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Do whatever they tell you--

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I mean, follow orders, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: With your attitude, Private, I'm surprised you want to stay in the service.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: I do, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Because it's a job?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Outside it's--it's such a mess--it's--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Chaos.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Why do you think they let us in on the "deal"?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: They got people to fight. Arabs, yellow people, whatever. Might as well use us.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Do you think you've been discriminated against on this post?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: No, sir. Not at all.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Any serious problems with your sergeant or your fellow soldiers?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: No, sir. They all been real straight with me.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: It works like this, Private--every soldier in a war doesn't have to believe in what he's fighting for. Most of them fight just to back up the soldiers in their squad--you try not to get them killed, try not to get them extra duty, try not to embarrass yourself in front of them.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Why don't you start with that?

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: You're dismissed, Private.

Speaker: athena
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: The Longhorns gonna kick some serious butt this Saturday, you just watch. We got a kid at tailback from down your way--outta El Indio--

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Oh. Right. And you're in--?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Rio. BUNNY Right. This kid, Hosea Brown? Does tire 40 in 3.4, soft hands, lateral movement--the whole package. Only a sophomore--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You still going to all the home games?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Well, Daddy's got his box at the stadium, of course, and I'll fly to the Cowboy away games when they're in the Conference. Then there's the high school on Friday' nights. West Side got a boy 6'6", 310, moves like a cat. High school, we're talkin'. Guess how much he can bench-press?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Bunny, you--uhm--you on that same medication?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Do I seem jumpy?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No, you look good. I was just wondering.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Last year was awful rough--Mama passing on and the whole business with O.J.--I mean it's not like it was Don Meredith or Roger Staubach or one of our own boys, but it really knocked me for a loop--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You look good--

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: --and that squeaker the Aggies dropped to Oklahoma-sonofabitch stepped in some lucky shit before he kicked that goal--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah, well--

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: --they hadn't pulled me off that woman I would have jerked a knot in her.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You were in a fight--

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Daddy calls it an "altercation." How you doing, Sam? You look skinny.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Same weight I always was.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: You look awful good in that uniform, though.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Best part of the job.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Daddy hired a pinhead to take your job. He says so himself. Says "Even my son-in-law was better than this pinhead I got now".

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Bunny, is that stuff I left in the garage still there?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Least he never called me that. With me, it was always "high-strung." "My Bunny might have done something with her life, she wasn't so high-strung." Or "tightly wound," that was another one. You seeing anyone?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: No. You?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Yeah. Sort of. Daddy rounds 'em up. You aren't talking about money, their beady little eyes go dead.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You didn't--uhm--you didn't have one of your fires, did you? The stuff I left in the garage--some of it was my father's--

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: You watch the draft this year? 'Course you didn't, idiot question. They try to make it dramatic, like there's some big surprise who picks who in the first round? Only they been working it over with their experts and their computers for months. Doctor's reports, highlight reels, coaches' evaluations, psychological profiles--hell, I wouldn't be surprised if they collected stool samples on these boys, have 'em analyzed. All this stuff to pick a football player for your squad. Compared to that, what you know about the person you get married to don't amount to diddly, does it?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Suppose not.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: You kind of bought yourself a pig in a poke, didn't you, Sam? All that time we were first seeing each other you didn't know I was tightly wound--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: It wasn't just you, Bunny.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: No, it wasn't, was it? You didn't exactly throw yourself into it heart and soul, did you?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Your shit's still in the garage if that's what you came for.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: 350 pounds.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: This boy from West Side, plays tackle both ways. Bench-presses 350 pounds. You imagine having that much weight on top of you? Pushing down? Be hard to breathe. Hard to swallow.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I think they have another fella there to keep it off your chest. A spotter.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: "I only got my little girl now," he says, "she's my lifeline." Then he tells me I can't be in the box anymore if I can't control myself. Sonofabitch don't even watch the damn game, just sits there drinking with his bidness friends, look up at the TV now and then. I do better to sit in the cheap seats with some real football people.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You look good, Bunny. It's nice to see you.

Speaker: bunny
Dialogue: Thanks. I like it when you say that, Sam.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Todos estamos? [Everybody here?]

Speaker: anselma
Dialogue: Van a disparar a nosotros? [Are they going to shoot at us?]

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Nadie nos veran. Seramos invisibles. Nobody's going to see us. We'll be invisible.]

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: "Dearest Buddy--"

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Hey, it's the General.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Colonel. Is uhm--is Otis in?

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Come on in--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: If it's too late--

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Come on in.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Otis sittin' up with some people at the club. I don't think he'll be long.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: His hot sauce recipe won a contest last year. They sellin' it far away as San Antonio. He got a lot of talent, your father.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: You've been in this house for a while?

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: I been here with him eight years now. He built it when he was with Leora.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: I never met her.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: There was a bunch of 'em You never met. Me neither.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Let me show you around--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Where'd he get all this?

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Your mother got a brother--Alphonse--

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Uncle Al--

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Otis stood on good terms with the man. Whenever you do something makes the news, he sends it on. When they made you General, Otis just about drove away all our customers going on about it.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: I'm a colonel.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Yeah, I know--Man made me memorize the whole damn Army chain of command before he'd marry me. So this is a big deal, commander and  all?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: It's a small post and they're phasing it out in two years, but I moved up in rank and--well, a command is a command.

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Otis went on like you were that guy who won the Gulf War. Colin whatsit.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: My mother said he never asked about--

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: He never asked her.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Listen, I uh--tell him I came by. Thanks--

Speaker: carolyn
Dialogue: Catch you later, Colonel.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Que Paso? [What happened?]

Speaker: nestor
Dialogue: Anselma cayo en las rocas. Creo que la pierna ha sido root--[Anselma felt on the rocks. I think her leg's broken--]

Speaker: nestor
Dialogue: No podemos alcanzar el camion llevando a ella. Hay lugar para esconderla? [We can't reach the truck if we're carrying her. Is there somewhere to hide her?]

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Conozco solamente una persona con casa--[I only know one person with a house--]

Speaker: anselma
Dialogue: Esta lejos? [Is it far?]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Quien es? [Who is it?]

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Soy yo, Enrique! No tiene miedo-- [It's me, Enrique. Don't be afraid]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: What are you doing out there? Are you crazy?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Hay pasado un accidente muy grave-- [There's been a bad accident--]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: In English, Enrique. We're in the United States--

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: I have some friends who have had a accident--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: You have somebody else out there?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: We was by the river? And I hear my friend callin' for help, and I look and she has falling in the water--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Don't tell me lies, Enrique. Que paso?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: We was crossin' the river--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Enrique! Quienes son estos? How could you bring them here?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: They need help. Jaime, Anselma-- esta es mi jefa--

Speaker: nestor
Dialogue: Senora--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I'll call the Border Patrol, they'll get her to the hospital.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: No! No puede hacer esto--[You can't do that--]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: You think you're doing these people a favor? What are they going to do? Either they get on welfare or they become criminals--

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: No es la verdad--[That isn't true--]

Speaker: nestor
Dialogue: Con permiso, Senora, la muchacha tiene mucho dolor--[Please, Senora, the girl is in a lot of pain--]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Sientase. [Sit.]

Speaker: nestor
Dialogue: Es muy amable. [You're very kind.]

Speaker: anselma
Dialogue: Ayudanos, Senora, por favor no podemos regresar--[Help us, Senora, please. We can't go back]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: This girl is a friend of yours?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Es mi novia. [She's my girlfriend.]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: I thought you were married!

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: I am marry to the cousin of a friend-- but only to be able to live here. This is the mother of my child--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: This girl has a child?

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: We have a daughter.

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Tipico.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hollis? You in there? Hollis?

Speaker: young mercedes
Dialogue: No puedo ver la orilla! [I can't see the bank!]

Speaker: young mercedes
Dialogue: Vi a Rosaria arastrado para el corriente--[I saw Rosaria taken away by the current--]

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: No te molestas. Tenemos a ella. [Don't worry. We've got her.]

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Como se llama? [What's your name?]

Speaker: young mercedes
Dialogue: Mercedes Gonzales Ruiz.

Speaker: eladio
Dialogue: Me llama Eladio Cruz--Bienvenido a Tejas. [Welcome to Texas.]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Rapidamente! Everybody in the world is going to see!

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Donde vamos? [Where are we going?]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: A casa de Porfirio Zayas. He used to be a doctor on the other side. Gunshot wounds, fixing babies--if you can pay he can handle it.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Senora, anything it costs, I can work--

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: Don't worry about it. He owes me some favors.

Speaker: enrique
Dialogue: Seas tranquila, mija.  Estamos en las manos de Senora Cruz. [Just relax, honey. We're in the hands of Senora Cruz.]

Speaker: mercedes
Dialogue: In English, Enrique. In English--

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: I finished that. I'm just messing around.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Tanks, huh?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: You got to be in the Army, you might as well have something slick to drive.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: So you're going into the Army?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: That's the general plan, isn't it?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: That's up to you.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: The Army isn't for everybody.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Not that I don't think you'd be good at it, but--you know--I wouldn't be disappointed if you decided to do something else with your life.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: You wouldn't?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: How's your room shaping up?

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Fine. I'm pretty much moved in.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Are we going to ever see your father?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: My father.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Yeah. He lives here, right?

Speaker: del
Dialogue: He does.

Speaker: del
Dialogue: Maybe we'll clean that thing out back up, have a barbecue next weekend. We could invite him and his wife over.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: Cool.

Speaker: chet
Dialogue: He makes his own sauce.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Fellas.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Hey, Sam.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Open late.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I'm not open. We were just talking.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Hollis probably told you we found Charley Wade.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Yeah. How about that? People start digging holes in this county, there's no telling what'll come up.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You two saw it, didn't you? You two saw it when Buddy killed him.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Imonna find out one way or the other.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Your father had the finest sense of justice of any man I ever met--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah, and my mother was a saint. For fifteen years the whole damn town knew he had another woman on the side. Stole ten thousand dollars to set her up in business. But hell, what's that? You got a problem? Buddy'll fix it. Facing some time in jail? Buddy'll knock half of it off-- if you do what he says, when he says. You got some business that's not exactly legal? Talk to Buddy--

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Buddy Deeds--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Buddy Deeds was a murderer.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: That night in the cafe--he didn't stay long after you left, did he, Hollis? Maybe he decided he'd gone too far with Wade, maybe he figured he better not wait for the Sheriff to get behind him. So he stepped out to see if he could catch up--and you were here at the club that night, weren't you, O?

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: I was here.

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Sheriff Charley had some real big friends in politics then, and if the truth come out it wasn't going to go easy on Hollis.  I don't know why I trusted Buddy with it--don't know why he trusted me. The first time I ever talked with him was right there, and then with a dead white man leakin' blood on the floor between us. He could charm the scales off a rattler, Buddy Deeds.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: The three of us cleaned up and took him to the post and put him under. Can't say I was much help.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: And the ten thousand?

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Widow's benefits. He figured it would make the disappearance look better, and that Mexican gal was just scrapin' by after Charley killed her man. They didn't get hooked up till late--

Speaker: otis
Dialogue: Time went on, people liked the story that we told better than anything the truth might have been.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: What's the call, Sam?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Don't think the Rangers are likely to find out any more than they already have.

Speaker: hollis
Dialogue: Word gets out who that body was, people are gonna think Buddy done it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Buddy's a goddamn legend. He can handle it.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: 'Night, fellas.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: When's the picture start?

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You gonna tell your mother we been seeing each other?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: She'll figure it out sooner or later. I don't have to ask permission anymore, if that's what you mean.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: You have any idea when your father died? Eladio?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Couple months before I was born--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Try a year and a half. He bands her an old snapshot. PILAR looks at it--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I've never seen my mother in a bathing suit before.  Didn't know she owned one.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Buddy bought the cafe for her with money he took from the county. Pilar looks away, struggling not to cry--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: They can't pull this on me. It isn't fair--I don't believe this--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: He paid the hospital bill when you were born. Your mom always calls you "our beautiful daughter" in the letters she wrote to him.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: From the first time I saw you at school--all those years we were married to other people I always felt like we were connected.

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: I remember thinking you were the one part of my life Buddy didn't have a piece of--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: So that's it? You're not going to want to be with me anymore?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: I'm not having any more children. After Amado, I had some complications-- I can't get pregnant again, if that's what the rule is about--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: If I met you for the first time today, I'd still want to be with you.

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: We start from scratch--

Speaker: sam
Dialogue: Yeah--

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Everything that went before, all that stuff, that history--the hell with it, right?

Speaker: pilar
Dialogue: Forget the Alamo.
